dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kicking us off today, uh, we've got some pretty big news on the education front. Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Pramila Jayapal, they've introduced this new bill.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kicking us off today, uh, we've got some pretty big news on the education front. Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Pramila Jayapal, they've introduced this new bill.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) on Wednesday introduced legislation to make college tuition free for millions of Americans, paid for by a new tax on Wall Street trades.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? The College for All plan, right? I, um, I saw something about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? The College for All plan, right? I, um, I saw something about that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone, and it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! So, it's pretty ambitious. It would basically make community college and trade school tuition-free for everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! So, it's pretty ambitious. It would basically make community college and trade school tuition-free for everyone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The College for All Plan would make community college and trade school tuition free for everyone...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, for everyone? That's, like, a huge deal. What about, um, four-year universities?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, for everyone? That's, like, a huge deal. What about, um, four-year universities?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good question. For public four-year colleges, it'd be tuition-free for families earning under $125,000 a year. And, uh, that same income bracket would get free tuition at private HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good question. For public four-year colleges, it'd be tuition-free for families earning under one hundred twenty five thousand dollars a year. And, uh, that same income bracket would get free tuition at private H B C U s and other minority-serving institutions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it would eliminate tuition at public four-year colleges and universities for students from families earning less than $125,000 per year. It would also make tuition free at private Historically Black Colleges and Universities and other minority-serving institutions for students from families in that income bracket.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so a bit of a, like, an income cap there. But still, that's a lot of people. And how are they, you know, planning to pay for all of this? Because that's always the big sticking point, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so a bit of a, like, an income cap there. But still, that's a lot of people. And how are they, you know, planning to pay for all of this? Because that's always the big sticking point, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. That's where the "Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act" comes in. They're proposing a new tax on stock trades, bond trades, and even derivatives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. That's where the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act comes in. They're proposing a new tax on stock trades, bond trades, and even derivatives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The federal investments in education and tuition would be paid for with a separate bill called the Tax on Wall Street Speculation Act, which would levy a new tax of 0.5% on stock trades, a 0.1% fee on bond trades and a 0.005% fee on derivatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, I remember Bernie pushing for something like this during his presidential runs, um, a financial transaction tax. So this isn't, like, a totally new idea for him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, I remember Bernie pushing for something like this during his presidential runs, um, a financial transaction tax. So this isn't, like, a totally new idea for him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This isnt the first time Sanders has pushed for a financial transaction taxhe floated the idea during his presidential campaign in 2016 and introduced legislation containing the tax in 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. He's been advocating for it for years. But the big number they're throwing out? They say this could raise $2.4 trillion over the next decade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. He's been advocating for it for years. But the big number they're throwing out? They say this could raise two point four trillion over the next decade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: $2.4 trillion. Thats how much the new tax on Wall Street transactions could raise over the next decade, according to a summary of the legislation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Two point four *trillion*? Wow. That's, uh, that's a lot of money. But I feel like I've heard different figures before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two point four trillion? Wow. That's, uh, that's a lot of money. But I feel like I've heard different figures before.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You're not wrong. The Tax Policy Center, when they looked at a similar proposal from Sanders, estimated it would only generate around $400 billion. So, like, a pretty significant difference there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're not wrong. The Tax Policy Center, when they looked at a similar proposal from Sanders, estimated it would only generate around four hundred billion. So, like, a pretty significant difference there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the Tax Policy Center analyzed Sanders campaign proposal for a financial transaction tax (a plan he said would raise $3 trillion over a decade), it concluded that the proposal would only generate about $400 billion in revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge gap. And I'm guessing not everyone's thrilled about a new tax on Wall Street, either.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge gap. And I'm guessing not everyone's thrilled about a new tax on Wall Street, either.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Critics, like, uh, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, they argue it would decrease returns for savers and make it harder for businesses to raise capital and create jobs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Critics, like, uh, the U S Chamber of Commerce, they argue it would decrease returns for savers and make it harder for businesses to raise capital and create jobs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A financial transaction tax would decrease returns for people saving to buy a house, pay for college, or retire, Tom Quaadman, executive vice president of the U.S. Chamber Center for Capital Markets Competitiveness, said in a statement reported by CNBC in 2019. It would also make it more expensive for businesses to raise the capital they need to start, expand, and create jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, it's a complicated one. On one hand, you want to help students avoid debt, but then, um, you have these concerns about market impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, it's a complicated one. On one hand, you want to help students avoid debt, but then, um, you have these concerns about market impact.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's a classic balancing act, you know? But it's definitely going to be a hot topic moving forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's a classic balancing act, you know? But it's definitely going to be a hot topic moving forward.
